title: BRICS
extract: BRICS is an intergovernmental organization consisting of ten countries—Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Iran and the United Arab Emirates. It is considered to be a counterpart and alternative to the G7 bloc of the world's largest economies and combined represent nearly half of the world's population.
trending_reason: The BRICS article is likely trending on Wikipedia due to the recent expansion of its membership and the upcoming 2025 summit under Brazil's chairmanship, reflecting its growing geopolitical influence.

title: Ryan_Day_(American_football)
extract: Ryan Patrick Day is an American football coach and former college football player. He is the 24th and current head football coach at Ohio State University, a position he has held since 2019. Day was also the acting head coach for the Ohio State Buckeyes for the first three games of the 2018 season. He attended the University of New Hampshire in Durham, New Hampshire, where he was a quarterback and linebacker for the Wildcats from 1998 to 2001 before beginning his coaching career in 2002.

ahead of the [[2025 College Football Playoff National Championship|2025 CFP National Championship]]. | current_title = [[Head coach]] | current_team = [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] | 2 [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] (2019, 2020)
3 [[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten East Division]] (2019–2021) | awards = [[Big Ten Conference football individual awards#Dave_McClain_/_Hayes–Schembechler_Coach_of_the_Year|Big Ten Coach of the Year]] (2019) | coaching_records = }} '''Ryan Patrick Day'''{{cite web|url=https://theozone.net/2020/12/forty-one-years-apart-game-deciding-interceptions-clemson-bowl-games-still-haunt-ohio-state/|title=Forty-One Years Apart, Game-Deciding Interceptions Against Clemson In Bowl Games Still Haunt Ohio State|last=Snook|first=Jeff|work=The O Zone|date=December 29, 2020|access-date=November 30, 2024}}{{cite web|url=https://govsalaries.com/salaries/head-coach-major-sports-salary|title=Head Coach Major Sports Salary|publisher=GovSalaries|access-date=December 1, 2024}} is an [[American football]] coach and former [[college football]] player. He is the 24th and current head football coach at [[Ohio State University]], a position he has held since 2019. Day was also the acting head coach for the [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State Buckeyes]] for the first three games of the [[2018 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|2018 season]]. He attended the [[University of New Hampshire]] in [[Durham, New Hampshire]], where he was a [[quarterback]] and [[linebacker]] for the [[New Hampshire Wildcats football|Wildcats]] from 1998 to 2001 before beginning his coaching career in 2002. ==Playing career== Day attended [[Manchester Central High School]] in [[Manchester, New Hampshire]].{{Cite web |last=Coppola |first=Frank |date=August 26, 2001 |title=There is little doubt about Ryan Day's role at UNH |url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/article/20010826/Sports/308269990 |access-date=February 1, 2015 |website=Sea Coast Online}} As a quarterback and defensive back, he was the state's [[Gatorade Player of the Year awards|Gatorade Player of the Year]] for his senior season. He then went to the [[New Hampshire Wildcats football|University of New Hampshire]]. Playing for then-offensive coordinator [[Chip Kelly]], Day set four career records at UNH including completion percentage and touchdowns.{{Cite web |last=Shorr-Parks |first=Eliot |date=January 23, 2015 |title=Here is what you need to know about Eagles' new quarterbacks coach Ryan Day |url=http://www.nj.com/eagles/index.ssf/2015/01/here_is_what_you_need_to_know_about_eagles_new_qua.html |access-date=February 1, 2015 |website=NJ.com}}{{Cite web |last=Wysong |first=David |date=December 19, 2020 |title=Ryan Day Was a Record-Setting Quarterback for Chip Kelly Before Becoming Ohio State's Head Coach |url=h
trending_reason: The Ryan Day article is trending on Wikipedia due to his recent achievement of winning the 2024 College Football Playoff National Championship, significantly enhancing his profile as the head coach of the Ohio State Buckeyes.

title: Will_Howard_(American_football)
extract: Will Howard is an American football quarterback for the Ohio State Buckeyes. Howard began his college football career at Kansas State before transferring to Ohio State in 2024, then winning the 2025 College Football National Championship.
text:
{{short description|American football quarterback (born 2001)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2024}} {{Infobox college football player | embed = | name = Will Howard | image = Will Howard interview.png | caption = Howard at Kansas State in 2020 | school = Ohio State Buckeyes | currentnumber = 18 | currentposition = [[Quarterback]] | class = {{redshirt}} Senior | major = Accounting | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|2001|9|24|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Downingtown, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 4 | weight_lb = 235 | highschool = [[Downingtown West High School|Downingtown West]]
([[Downingtown, Pennsylvania]]) | bowlgames = * [[2022 Sugar Bowl (December)|2022 Sugar Bowl]] * [[2025 Rose Bowl]] * [[2025 Cotton Bowl Classic (January)|2025 Cotton Bowl]] (Off. MVP) *[[2025 College Football Playoff National Championship|2025 CFP National Championship]] (Off. MVP) | pastschools = * [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State]] (2020–2023) * [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State]] (2024–present) | highlights = * [[College Football Playoff National Championship|CFP national champion]] ([[2025 College Football Playoff National Championship|2024]]) * [[College Football Playoff National Championship#MVPs|CFP National Championship Game Offensive MVP]] (2025) * Second-team All-[[Big 12 Conference|Big 12]] ([[2023 Big 12 Conference football season|2023]]) * Third-team All-[[Big Ten Conference|Big Ten]] ([[2024 All-Big Ten Conference football team|2024]]) * | espn = 4429955 }} '''Will Howard''' (born September 24, 2001) is an [[American football]] [[quarterback]] for the [[Ohio State Buckeyes football|Ohio State Buckeyes]]. Howard began his [[college football]] career at [[Kansas State Wildcats football|Kansas State]] before transferring to Ohio State in 2024, then winning the 2025 College Football National Championship. ==Early life== Howard grew up in [[Downingtown, Pennsylvania]], and attended [[Downingtown West High School]].{{cite web|url=https://www.inquirer.com/high-school-sports/pennsylvania/will-howard-downington-west-recruiting-kansas-state-20190812.html|title=Football recruiting: Downingtown West's Will Howard finds 'home' with Carson Wentz's former coach|first=Phil|last=Anastasia|work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=August 12, 2019|access-date=November 14, 2022}}{{cite web|url=https://www.inquirer.com/philly/sports/high_school/pennsylvania/conwell-egan-patrick-garwo-downingtown-west-will-howard-high-school-football-leaders-20180926.html|title=Downingtown West's Will Howard is top passer|work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=September 26, 2018|access-date=November 18, 2022}} He was named the [[Maxwell Football Club]] Pennsylvania Player of the Year after passing for 2,543 yards and 27 touchdowns as a senior.{{cite web|url=https://www.inquirer.com/high-school-sports/pennsylvania/will-howard-dowingtown-west-high-school-football-player-of-year-kansas-state-20191213.html|title=Downingtown West's Will Howard is player of year|first=Phil|last=Anastasia|work=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date=December 13, 2019|access-date=November 14, 2022}} Howard finished his high school career with 5,308 passing yards and 48 touchdown passes while also rushing for 512 yards and 21 touchdowns.{{cite web|url=https://themercury.com/k_state_sports/will-howard-might-be-called-upon-to-start-at-quarterback-for-kansas-state-on-saturday/article_7afe10c3-0d0f-5c40-8f84-25b6c629f729.html|title=Will Howard might be called upon to start at quarterback for Kansas State on Saturday|work=[[The Manhattan Mercury]]|date=October 9, 2020|access-date=November 16, 2022}} He also was a two-time All-Area selection in basketball and scored over 1,000 points in his varsity career.{{cite web|url=https://www.kstatecollegian.com/2021/08/20/countdown-to-kickoff-15-days-away-with-quarterback-will-howard-defensive-tackle-robert-hentz-ii/|title=Countdown to Kickoff: 15 days away with quarterback Will Howard, defensive tackle Robert Hentz II|first=Colin|last=Settle|work=[[Kansas State Collegian]]|date=August 20, 2021|access-date=November 16, 2022}} Howard was rated a three-star recruit and received more than 20 total scholarship offers. He committed to play college football at Kansas State after considering offers from [[Maryland Terrapins football|Maryland]], [[Minnesota Golden Gophers football|Minnesota]], [[Rutgers Scarlet Knights football|Rutgers]], and [[Kansas Jayhawks football|Kansas]].{{cite web|url=https://n.rivals.com/news/quarterback-will-howard-commits-to-kansas-state|title=Quarterback Will Howard commits to Kansas State|first=Derek|last=Young|website=[[Rivals.com]]|date=June 23, 2019|access-date=November 14, 2022}} ==College career== ===Kansas State=== Howard joined th
trending_reason: The Will Howard article is trending on Wikipedia following his standout performance as the Offensive MVP in the 2025 College Football Playoff National Championship, solidifying his reputation as a key player for the Ohio State Buckeyes after transferring from Kansas State.

title: World_Health_Organization
extract: The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for global public health. It is headquartered in Geneva, Switzerland, and has six regional offices and 150 field offices worldwide. Only sovereign states are eligible to join, and it is the largest intergovernmental health organization at the international level.
text:
{{Short description|Specialized agency of the United Nations}} {{Redirect2|WHO|The WHO|other uses|Who (disambiguation)|the band|The Who}} {{Duplicated citations|reason=[[User:Polygnotus/DuplicateReferences|DuplicateReferences]] detected:
* http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/62873/1/14549_eng.pdf (refs: 13, 14, 15, 16)
* https://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/39485 (refs: 32, 33)
* https://web.archive.org/web/20120617074331/http://whqlibdoc.who.int/pb/2012-2013/PB_2012%E2%80%932013_eng.pdf (refs: 76, 255)
* http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2011/9789241501651_eng.pdf (refs: 77, 78)
* https://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2017/director-general-elect/en/ (refs: 213, 256)
* https://web.archive.org/web/20160304104615/http://www.who.int/civilsociety/documents/en/RevreportE.pdf (refs: 250, 251)
|date=January 2025}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2023}} {{Use Oxford spelling|date=October 2020}} {{Infobox organization | name = World Health Organization | native_name = {{Collapsible list | title = In other [[Official languages of the United Nations|official languages]]: | {{langx|arb|منظمة الصحة العالمية|rtl=yes}} | {{langx|zh|世界卫生组织}} | {{langx|fr|Organisation mondiale de la santé |italic=unset}} | {{langx|ru|Всемирная организация здравоохранения}} | {{langx|es|Organización Mundial de la Salud|italic=unset}}}} | logo = World Health Organization Logo.svg | logo_size = 250px | image = World Health Organization @ Pregny-Chambésy (50636746028).jpg | caption = The headquarters in [[Geneva]] was designed by [[Jean Tschumi]] and inaugurated in 1966.{{cite web|url=https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/documents/about-us/modernizing-who-headquarters.pdf|title=Modernizing the WHO headquarters in Geneva|access-date=5 January 2023|archive-date=15 January 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230115111613/https://cdn.who.int/media/docs/default-source/documents/about-us/modernizing-who-headquarters.pdf|url-status=live}} | image_size = | map = | map_size = | map_caption = | type = [[List of specialized agencies of the United Nations|United Nations specialized agency]] | abbreviation = WHO | pronounce = Initialism (''W-H-O'') by WHO itself and governmental stakeholders | leader_title = [[Director-General of the World Health Organization|Director-General]] | leader_name = [[Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus]] | leader_title2 = Deputy Director General | leader_name2 = [[Michael J. Ryan (doctor)|Michael Ryan]] | status = Active | formation = {{start date and age|df=y|1948|4|7}} | headquarters = [[Geneva]], Switzerland {{coord|46|13|56|N|06|08|03|E|type:landmark_region:CH-GE|display=title,inline}} | website = {{URL|https://www.who.int/|who.int}} | parent_organization = [[United Nations Economic and Social Council]] | subsidiaries = | budget = $6.83 billion (2024–25) }} The '''World Health Organization''' ('''WHO''') is a [[list of specialized agencies of the United Nations|specialized agency]] of the [[United Nations]] responsible for global [[public health]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/fact-sheet/the-u-s-government-and-the-world-health-organization/|title=The U.S. Government and the World Health Organization|date=24 January 2019|website=The Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=18 March 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200318223306/https://www.kff.org/global-health-policy/fact-sheet/the-u-s-government-and-the-world-health-organization/|archive-date=18 March 2020|url-status=live}} It is headquartered in [[Geneva]], Switzerland, and has six regional offices{{Cite web |title=Regional offices |url=https://www.who.int/about/who-we-are/regional-offices |access-date=2024-04-20 |website=www.who.int |language=en |archive-date=20 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240420013909/https://www.who.int/about/who-we-are/regional-offices |url-status=live }} and 150 field offices worldwide. Only sovereign states are eligible to join, and it is the largest intergovernmental health organization at the international level.{{Cite web |title=WHO (World Health Organisation) |url=https://internews.org/covid-19/glossary/who/ |access-date=2 March 2023 |website=Information Saves Lives {{!}} Internews |language=en-US |archive-date=2 March 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230302110349/https://internews.org/covid-19/glossary/who/ |url-status=live }} The WHO's purpose is to achieve the highest possible level of health for all the world's people, defining health as "a st
trending_reason: The World Health Organization article is trending on Wikipedia due to ongoing global discussions about its role and effectiveness in addressing public health challenges, particularly in the wake of recent health crises and its evolving strategies under the leadership of Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.

title: Mariann_Budde
extract: Mariann Edgar Budde is an American prelate of the Episcopal Church. She has served as Bishop of Washington since November 2011. Before being elected Washington's first female diocesan bishop, she served 18 years as rector of St. John's Episcopal Church in Minneapolis, Minnesota.
text:
{{Short description|American Episcopal bishop (born 1959/1960)}} {{pp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2025}} {{Infobox Christian leader | honorific-prefix = [[The Right Reverend]] | name = Mariann Budde | honorific-suffix = | bishop_of = [[Episcopal Diocese of Washington|Bishop of Washington]] | image = Mariann Budde at Neil Armstrong public memorial service.jpg | caption = Budde in 2012 | church = [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] | diocese = [[Episcopal Diocese of Washington|Washington]] | see = | enthroned = November 12, 2011 | term = 2011–present | ended = | elected = June 18, 2011 | predecessor = [[John Bryson Chane]] | successor = | ordination = May 28, 1988 ([[Deacon#Anglicanism|deacon]])
March 4, 1989 ([[Anglican priest|priest]]) | consecration = November 12, 2011 | consecrated_by = [[Katharine Jefferts Schori]] | other_post = | birth_date = 1959 | birth_place = [[New Jersey]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | buried = | religion = [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] | residence = | parents = | spouse = Paul Budde | children = 2 | education = [[University of Rochester]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])
[[Virginia Theological Seminary]] ([[Master of Divinity|MDiv]], [[Doctor of Ministry|DMin]]) }} '''Mariann Edgar Budde''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|ʌ|d|i}}; born 1959) is an American [[prelate]] of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]]. She has served as [[Episcopal Diocese of Washington|Bishop of Washington]] since November 2011. Before being elected Washington's first female diocesan bishop, she served 18 years as [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of St. John's Episcopal Church in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. ==Early life and education== Mariann Edgar Budde was born in 1959 in [[New Jersey]],{{cite news |first1=Paul |last1=Ferrell |first2=Katie |last2=Hawkinson |date=January 22, 2025 |title=Brave bishop tells Trump to his face 'Have mercy on trans children and immigrants – they are scared of you'|newspaper=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/trump-nasty-bishop-mariann-budde-b2683911.html |access-date=2025-01-22}}''Episcopal Clerical Directory 2013'' (2013). New York: Church Publishing Inc. {{ISBN|978-0-89869-888-6}}, p. 138. to William Edgar and Ann Björkman (1931–2024).{{cite news|url=https://www.goinghomecares.com/obituaries/Ann-B-Edgar?obId=34361581|title=Obituary Ann B Edgar|via=goinghomecares.com}} Her mother was [[Swedish American]].{{cite news|url=http://episcopalelections.com/elections/minnesota/nominees/BuddeBio.pdf|title=Mariann Edgar Budde: Autobiographical Statement|via=Jeffrey L. Diehl, EpiscopalElections.com}} Budde grew up in the [[Flanders, New Jersey|Flanders]] section of [[Mount Olive Township, New Jersey]], attending [[Mount Olive High School (New Jersey)|West Morris Mount Olive High School]], and also in [[Colorado]], following her parents' separation.{{Cite news |last=Dias |first=Elizabeth |last2=Balk |first2=Tim |date=2025-01-21 |title=Who Is Mariann Edgar Budde, the Bishop Who Made a Plea to Trump? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/21/us/politics/bishop-mariann-edgar-budde-trump.html |access-date= |work=[[The New York Times]] |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}[https://www.newspapers.com/article/daily-record-08may1977-honor-roll/109831253/ "West Morris Names High Hinor Roll"], ''[[Daily Record (New Jersey)|Daily Record]]'', May 8, 1977. Accessed January 23, 2025, via [[Newspapers.com]]. "The following West Morris-Mount Olive High School students have been named to the high honor roll for the third marking period." She completed her undergraduate work at the [[University of Rochester]] in 1982,George Gandy, [https://www.rochesterfirst.com/rochester/bishop-in-trumps-inaugural-prayer-service-graduated-from-university-of-rochester/ Bishop in Trump's inaugural prayer service graduated from University of Rochester], WROC (January 23, 2025). earning a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in history ''magna cum laude''.{{cite web |title=Bishop Mariann Edgar Budde |website=Episcopal Diocese of Washington |date=26 April 2021 |url=https://edow.org/about/bishop-mariann/ |access-date=22 January 2025}} She received her [[Master of Divinity]] (1989) and [[Doctor of Ministry]] (2008) degrees from the [[Virginia Theological Seminary]]. ==Career== ===Early career=== Budde worked in urban ministry in [[Arizona]] and then as a missionary in [[Honduras]] before joining the clergy.Paul O'Donnell, [https://www.washingtonian.com/2014/07/03/what-made-me-mariann-edgar-budde/ What Made Me: Mariann Edgar Budde], ''Washingtonian'' (July 3, 2014). She was accepted as a [[postulant]] in the Episcopal Church at the age
trending_reason: The Mariann Budde article is trending on Wikipedia following her recent public plea to former President Trump regarding the treatment of trans children and immigrants, which has garnered significant media attention and sparked discussions on social justice and religious leadership.

news_relation:
Bishop Mariann Budde is in the news for her sermon during an inaugural prayer service where she appealed to President Trump to show mercy towards marginalized communities, which has sparked controversy.
  • Bishop Mariann Budde tells NPR 'I won't apologize' for sermon addressing Trump Bishop Budde discussed her hope that President Trump's new administration would show compassion.
  • Trump demands an apology from bishop who asked him to ‘have mercy’ on LGBTQ+ people and migrants President Trump is demanding an apology from Bishop Budde after her plea during the service.
  • Bishop Mariann Budde defends plea directed at Trump during inaugural prayer service Budde defended her appeal for mercy on behalf of immigrants and others during the service.
